title: Dwayne Peel
text:
Dwayne John Peel (born 31 August 1981) is a former <a href="Welsh%20people">Welsh</a> <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player. He was the most capped <a href="Scrum-half%20%28rugby%20union%29">scrum-half</a> for the <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales national rugby union team</a> with 76 caps, until his record was surpassed by <a href="Mike%20Phillips%20%28rugby%20player%29">Mike Phillips</a> on 16 March 2013.
Youth and early career.
Peel was born in <a href="Carmarthen">Carmarthen</a>, Wales. He started his rugby career playing for <a href="Tumble%20RFC">Tumble RFC</a> at Under-8s level. He attended in <a href="Cefneithin">Cefneithin</a>, and is a fluent <a href="Welsh%20language">Welsh</a> speaker. He made his professional club debut for <a href="Llanelli%20RFC">Llanelli RFC</a> before joining the <a href="Scarlets">Llanelli Scarlets</a> region at its creation in 2003.
International.
Peel made his international debut for <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales</a> in 2001 against <a href="Japan%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Japan</a>. He was still on his geography degree course at the <a href="Swansea%20University">Swansea University</a> at the time. During his time at Swansea University, he became friends with Edward Lewsey – a Welsh Under-21 international, and brother of England international <a href="Josh%20Lewsey">Josh Lewsey</a>. Peel has since scored five tries (25 points) scoring his debut Test try against Italy in 2003 for Wales.
In 2005, Peel was selected for the <a href="2005%20British%20%26amp%3B%20Irish%20Lions%20tour%20to%20New%20Zealand">British & Irish Lions tour to New Zealand</a>, and was the youngest Lion on the tour. On 9 September 2007, Peel was captain for Wales when they beat Canada 42–17 in their opening match in the 2007 Rugby World Cup.
On 15 January 2008, it was announced by the Scarlets that Peel would be joining <a href="Sale%20Sharks">Sale Sharks</a> at the end of the <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20Celtic%20League">2007–08 season</a>. 
Peel joined, on a three-year contract, at the start of the 2008–09 season.
New <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales</a> coach <a href="Warren%20Gatland">Warren Gatland</a> later stated that Peel would be an exception to his desired policy to select players from those playing for Welsh clubs, but on 19 January 2009 it was announced that Peel would not be part of the <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Welsh</a> squad for the <a href="2009%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2009 Six Nations Championship</a>. Peel was subsequently called into the squad, however, as cover for injured <a href="Gareth%20Cooper">Gareth Cooper</a> and on 8 February 2009 played in the second half of Wales' opening match against Scotland.
In the 2012-2013 Premiership season, Peel was involved in the 32-9 win on 12 April against <a href="Gloucester%20Rugby">Gloucester</a>, scoring two tries. He was also named in the Barbarians squad for the 2013 Summer internationals, to play against <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a> and the <a href="British%20%26amp%3B%20Irish%20Lions">British & Irish Lions</a>.
Peel then signed for <a href="Bristol%20Rugby">Bristol Rugby</a> for the 2014–15 season, being appointed club captain in the process playing alongside Welsh internationals Ryan Jones and Ian Evans.
Coaching.
On 15 February 2017, <a href="Ulster%20Rugby">Ulster</a> announced Peel would join them as Assistant Coach from the start of the 2017/18 season on a two-year contract.
Peel was due to join the <a href="Cardiff%20Blues">Cardiff Blues</a> for the 2021–22 season as senior assistant coach responsible for attack.
However, Peel joined the Scarlets as Head coach for the 2021-22 season instead.
